title: This week's circle jerk: The mage holocaust!
body:
Greetings and welcome to today's segment of "Weekly Circlejerk", a (potentially) weekly thread that goes over the spiciest and most talked about topics on the gameplay boards.
Today I present you the topic of many heated debates and salty threads: The supposedly "weak" state of Mages.

Over the last week the front-page was flooded with threads lamenting the "horrible" state mages are in and how they've been pushed out of their natural habitat of mid lane by the nefarious archetype known as the common Marksman, often going by the abbreviation ADC for Attack Damage Carry.
Apparently this creature has migrated from its nesting spots in the bottom lane and has invaded the middle one, threatening to push out Magic-damage champions out from their natural habitat.

_______________________________

Or so the boards would want you to believe.

According to statistics there are only two AD, Attack Damage, champions in  top 15 mid lane champions.
https://www2.pic-upload.de/img/34016900/Bildschirmfoto2017-10-02um09.26.29.png

Both of which do not fall into the "Marksman" category but are rather Assassins or  fighters.

But Winrates aren't everything, so perhaps pick rates would be the more suitable statistic to document AP champions going extinct in mid lane, pushed out but Marksmen.

But even then there's no sign of the supposedly alarming occurrence of Marksmen taking up the place of traditional mages.
https://www2.pic-upload.de/img/34016899/Bildschirmfoto2017-10-02um09.26.46.png

The most popular mid lane champions are still, in fact, mostly mages with the occasional assassin.

And even then, to conclude this little accumulation of stats, the posterboy for Marksmen going mid, Lucian the Purifier, is sitting at a not so comfortable 43% win rate despite having a somewhat respectable pick rate of 5 %
https://www2.pic-upload.de/img/34016897/Bildschirmfoto2017-10-02um09.27.22.png


__________________________


Based on these stats I presented we may deduce that this uproar about Marksmen pushing out traditional mages out of their natural habitat is nothing more than a baseless claim, with Mages still reigning supreme in the middle lane.
This 'Mage Holocaust' seems to be just another sign of how these boards underplay the strength of the mage class and combining this notion of "weak" AP champions with the current "OP" Marksmen bandwagon makes for one hell of a circle jerk!

Join me next week for yet another installment of "Weekly Circlejerk" where I will dissect next week's hot topic!


-Malicious Metal, phD in Mordelogy and Boards Science

Because the thing ADCs and Mages have in common is that they're both supposed to be carries. However, Riot has been taking away a Mages capacity to solo carry and orienting them to be more utilitarian than actual carries. A Mage certainly _can_ still carry, but emphasis has been taken away from them and placed on the ADC.

In addition, there have been a lot of recent additions to make Mages unable to carry unlike an ADC, and that is their Support. Supports have gotten more than excellent tools to protect their carries and enhance them as well, making it unlikely a Mage will be able to kill the ADC themselves while benefiting significantly less from their own Support. It's often the better play to support and pell for your own ADC, rather than be an APC.

Mages don't have anywhere else to go really, If you try to move them somewhere else you'll generally get flamed for the pick and really you're still facing the same problem in other lanes as you are in mid lane. The reason why Mage players get annoyed when ad champs become prevalent AT ALL in mid lane is almost entirely because of itemization, more so than the mage's or ad champs themselves. 

Because ad champs don't have to worry about running out of mana as much they can build basically whatever need to to deal with the situation at hand. Things going well? Build some armor pen. Things not going well? Build a maw. Getting poked a little? Build some life steal. Not being significantly gated by mana allows these champions to instantly adapt or take advantage. 

When I'm playing my mages mid lane it basically goes like this. 

Am I worried about getting bursted down? If so work towards a rod of ages. No matter how good or bad things get I must build catalyst first. 
Am I not worried about getting bursted down? If so work towards morellonomicon. No matter how good or bad things get I must build {{item:3802}} first. 

If I don't I am relying entirely on the ability of my team to deliver a blue buff to me. As so, not very reliable. 

The long and the short of it is that mages don't have a good, standard item to answer an AD mid, which makes playing against them feel much worse than it should. Zhonyas is a piece of garbage, it is picked all the time because  mages have no other options, but it's still a shitty item. Mages need an ap armor item that gives them a pool of mana. It doesn't even have to offer a lot of armor, just enough to avoid taking true damage the second your ad opponent builds some armor pen.
